Context:
Program Name: Project Management
Code: B425
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 8 months (2 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,439.00 *
Location: Online
Experiential Learning: Simulated Learning Environment.
Program Overview: A postgraduate certificate program in Project Management (Online). Students will be able to manage project scopes, changes, innovation, goal setting, project management, staffing, risk management, use project management tools, and perform other tasks in careers that involve project management.
Flexibility: Part of the college's online postgraduate programs offering working professionals flexibility with live, instructor-led classes scheduled in the evening and on weekends.
Skills Acquired: Knowledge and skills to succeed in business and project management, implementing Project Management Institute knowledge areas like processes, lifecycle phases, and embodied concepts, and adapting projects in response to issues.
Note: This program is also offered full-time in person. For more information, see the Project Management postgraduate program (B415).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Online) (Postgraduate) B425 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text is about a Project Management postgraduate program offered by the Centre for Business in the School of Management at the college. The program can be taken online or full-time in person. Students will learn skills such as applying project management practices, aligning projects to organizational plans, helping projects succeed, and adapting project management practices to various industries.

Technical requirements for the program include a computer running on Windows 10 or Mac OSX with the latest updates and virus protection software, high-speed broadband access, a microphone and headphones or speakers, a webcam (potentially required), and a web browser. Students will participate in a field-based course where they gain experience in defining requirements, creating project plans, tracking budgets, coordinating meetings, monitoring progress, assessing risks, managing stakeholders, implementing management tools, preparing reports, and conducting themselves professionally.

Graduates of the program may pursue careers as junior project managers, team leaders, project coordinators, project administrators, or project analysts. The text also mentions that George Brown's Project Management field education course has allowed industries to work with students on new projects.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Online) (Postgraduate) B425 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text mentions the following key information related to George Brown College and its Project Management Program:

1. George Brown College has a partnership with the Retail Council of Canada where PM students help develop operational procedures in membership and event management.
2. George Brown College is recognized as a Global Registered Education Provider by the Project Management Institute (PMI).
3. Graduates of any of the George Brown College courses listed on PMI’s Registered Education Provider portal will have satisfied the education requirements to apply for PMI's Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) or Project Management Professional (PMP) certification.
4. The Project Management Institute recognizes George Brown College as a Global Registered Education Provider, and its PMP and CAPM certifications are industry-recognized.
5. To apply for the PMP certification, you need either: a secondary degree with at least five years of project management experience and 7,500 hours leading and directing projects or a four-year degree with at least three years of project management experience and 4,500 hours leading and directing projects. You will exceed the 35 hours' education requirement upon completion of George Brown College’s B425 Project Management Program.
6. To apply for the CAPM certification, you need a secondary degree and at least 1,000 hours of experience in leading or directly contributing to one or more project teams. You will also exceed the 35 hours' education requirement upon completion of George Brown College’s B425 Project Management Program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Online) (Postgraduate) B425 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The B425 Project Management Program is an online program offered by the college for domestic students only. It requires completion of nine mandatory courses. Here are the details of the courses in each semester:

Semester 1:
- Week 1–14: MGMT 4017 Organizational Behaviour (no prerequisite)
- Week 1–7: MGMT 4015 Scope and Quality Management (no prerequisite)
- Week 1–7: MGMT 4019 Risk Management (no prerequisite)
- Week 8–14: MGMT 4085 Schedule and Cost Management (no prerequisite)
- Week 8–14: MGMT 4057 Project Planning and Client Management (no prerequisite)

Semester 2:
- Code and pre-requisite details not provided

To graduate from the program, students need to complete all nine mandatory courses. The PMP or CAPM exams are related to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK version 6), which is published by the Project Management Institute (PMI). The B425 Program will assist students preparing for these exams as its course materials are based on PMBOK version 6.

To sit for the CAPM exam, students need a secondary degree and at least 1,500 hours of project experience or 23 hours of project management education. The program exceeds the 35 hours' education requirement upon completion. The CAPM exam consists of 150 multiple-choice questions.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Online) (Postgraduate) B425 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Project Management Information:
- Identify project goals, constraints, deliverables, performance criteria, control needs, and resource requirements in consultation with stakeholders.
- Implement PMI project management knowledge areas, processes, lifecycle phases, concepts, tools and techniques.
- Adapt projects in response to issues that arise internally and externally.
- Interact with team and stakeholders in a professional manner.
- Utilize technology tools for communication, collaboration, information management, and decision support.
- Implement general business concepts, practices, and tools to facilitate project success.
- Reflect on their role and effectiveness as a leader and follower.
- Apply appropriate legal and ethical standards.
- Adapt project management practices to meet the needs of stakeholders from various sectors.
- Apply project management practices to the launch of new programs, initiatives, products, services, and events.
- Appraise the role of project management in organizational change.

Program-Related Information:
- Fall 2023 start date for programs
- Estimated tuition for first two semesters: $4,439.00 *
- Additional costs (subject to change): not provided
- OSAP funding approval for this program
- Admission requirements: college advanced diploma or bachelor's degree or relevant work experience with resume and references required.
- English language proficiency requirement: applicants with international transcripts without English proficiency test results must take the George Brown College English assessment for consideration. Work experience applicants must provide proof of English proficiency at the college level, and may be required to write the George Brown College English admission assessment.

* Note that this tuition fee does not include books which are to be purchased separately by the student.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Project Management Program (Online) (Postgraduate) B425 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: English proficiency requirements can be found on the George Brown College website. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions, more information can be found in the transfer guide. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Information sessions are held regularly on campus. Interested individuals can sign up for an upcoming session. For domestic admission inquiries, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section. International students should contact international recruitment representatives specialized by country of origin via virtual meeting or submission of an inquiry, more information can be found on the International Contact Us page. For financial aid inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section. Entry advising appointments can be made to see an advisor for advice on program options and which program might be best suited. The Centre for Business can be contacted at business@georgebrown.ca or (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. Saifur Rahman is the Program Co-ordinator for Project Management (B425), his email address is mdsaifur.rahman@georgebrown.ca. The Centre for Business program is offered through the School of Management and classes are offered fully online or in scheduled, live sessions. Campus tours can be arranged.
